    RETURN TO ISSUEPREVPerspectiveNEXT

    Emerging Substrate Proteins of Kelch-like ECH Associated Protein 1 (Keap1) and Potential Challenges for the Development of Small-Molecule Inhibitors of the Keap1-Nuclear Factor Erythroid 2-Related Factor 2 (Nrf2) Protein–Protein Interaction

      Yong Zhang

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The activation of nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) is believed to combat both oxidative stress and inflammation as a promising strategy to treat chronic diseases. Recently, directly inhibiting the protein–protein interaction (PPI) between Nrf2 and Kelch-like ECH associated protein 1 (Keap1) has emerged as an attractive strategy to activate Nrf2 in organisms. The current development of Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors is mainly based on the interaction between Keap1 and the Nrf2 ETGE motif. However, a group of proteins that feature an ETGE motif similar to that of Nrf2 have emerged as new substrates of Keap1 over the past decade. In this Perspective, we focus on the potential off-target actions of current Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors and discuss their impact on future drug development. We also propose that a DLGex-based strategy aiming to inhibit the Keap1-Nrf2 DLGex interaction would help the development of small molecules with better target selectivity.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As the elderly population is dramatically increasing in modern society, aging has become the greatest risk factor for a spectrum of chronic diseases. At the same time, the need for novel therapies to promote healthy aging is growing. Most age-related chronic diseases share some basic mechanistic pillars that largely converge on low-grade oxidative stress and inflammation.(1,2) The targeting of these common driving forces is believed to be a promising strategy to develop therapies to prevent or possibly cure multiple diseases with one medicinal agent.(1)
    Nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) has been characterized as one of the most important regulators of the cellular defense system against oxidative stress, as well as inflammatory insults.(3,4) By binding the antioxidant response elements (AREs) in promoter regions, Nrf2 regulates the transcription of approximately 250 genes, which together build a multifaceted network that integrates cellular activities including detoxification reactions, the maintenance of both redox and protein homeostasis, and energy metabolism.(5) In recent years, therapies based on the activation of Nrf2 to combat both oxidative stress and inflammation have been proposed to be beneficial in chronic diseases.(1,6−8) The activity of Nrf2 is negatively regulated by the Kelch-like ECH associated protein 1 (Keap1), which promotes the ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation of Nrf2 in the cytoplasmic compartment.(9−14) Although other proteins and alternative mechanisms also control the activity of Nrf2,(15,16) Keap1 is currently the principal target to activate Nrf2 in organisms. While the inhibition of Keap1 through the reversible covalent modification of reactive cysteines has been clinically validated as a feasible strategy,(17−19) directly inhibiting the Keap1-Nrf2 protein–protein interaction (PPI) has recently emerged as a promising alternative strategy that is assumed to have higher target selectivity than covalent Keap1 inhibitors (or Nrf2 activators) and thus reduce unknown safety risks.(8,20−23) In recent years, much progress has been made in the field of direct Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors, as a series of highly potent small-molecule inhibitors have been reported.(7,8,21,23)
    In parallel with the advances in the Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitor field, biological studies on Keap1 have also made substantial progress in dissecting the Keap1 protein interaction network (PIN).(24−27) Interestingly, a group of proteins that contain the ETGE(-like) or the DLGex(-like) motifs were found to be enriched within the network.(28) Therefore, in a broader sense, Keap1 acts as the substrate recognition module of Cul3-Rbx1 E3 ligase complex that specifically sequesters substrates harboring these two motifs and not merely as an inhibitor of Nrf2. Indeed, Keap1 has been observed to carry out diverse Nrf2-independent functions by regulating the activity of other substrates, which will be described later in this review. An important question has thus arisen: would currently available Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors, which were originally designed to activate Nrf2 by blocking the substrate-binding pocket of Keap1, also affect the functions of other substrates? If so, these previously unrealized off-target actions might bring uncertainty to future drug development activities. This review is mainly aimed at discussing these potential challenges, which have only been scarcely addressed in the field of Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitor. In this review, we will first describe the structure of Keap1 with a special focus on its substrate-binding domain. Next, we will depict both physical and functional interactions between Keap1 and reported substrates, including Nrf2 and emerging substrates. Then, we will review current progress in the development of small-molecule inhibitors of the Keap1-Nrf2 PPI, followed by a discussion on how the emerging substrates of Keap1 will challenge drug development and the possible strategies that we could adopt to overcome these challenges and improve target selectivity.

    2. Keap1 as the Substrate Recognition Module for the Cul3-Rbx1 E3 Ubiquitin Ligase

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As a member of the Kelch-like (KLHL) protein family, Keap1 has a typical KLHL structure and is composed of an N-terminal Broad-Complex, Tramtrack, and Bric-à-Brac (BTB) domain, an intermediate intervening region (IVR) domain, and a C-terminal Kelch domain that comprises six Kelch repeats (Figure 1A).(29,30) The BTB domain mediates both the dimerization of Keap1 monomers and the interaction between Keap1 and the Cul3-Rbx1 E3 ubiquitin ligase (CRL3) complex.(31−34) The multimodular CRL3 complex contains a Cullin3 scaffold that links to a substrate-recognition module (SRM) and a catalytic module at its two terminal ends (Figure 1B).(35) Keap1 binds the Cullin3 scaffold and functions as the SRM.(13,14,34)
    Keap1 recognizes and captures substrates through its Kelch domain, which adopts a symmetrical six-bladed β-propeller structure.(34,36) Each blade contains a four-stranded (βA to βD) antiparallel β-sheet (Figure 2A). The strands in the sheet are connected by loops of various lengths. Short loops that connect βA and βB (AB loops) or βC and βD (CD loops) are projected to one side of the propeller, while long BC and DA loops are projected to the other side, where they gather and create a small, shallow pocket for substrate binding.(33,34,36) On the basis of cocrystal structures of the Keap1-Nrf2 ETGE complex and the Keap1-Nrf2 DLGex complex, this binding pocket can be artificially subdivided into six subpockets, namely, P1–P6 (Figure 2B).(20,21,37−39) Both subpockets P1 and P2 are highly positively charged due to the presence of multiple arginine residues (Arg415, Arg483, and Arg485). This property enables these sites to recognize and tightly clasp the negatively charged amino acid residues of substrates, which provides the greatest driving force for substrate binding. The central P3 subpocket is made up of small polar and nonpolar residues and serves as the anchoring site for the scaffold of the substrate peptide. The presence of interacting residues with large and long side chains in the P3 site is unfavorable.(37,40) For example, the substitution of Gly with Ala in the Nrf2 ETGE motif (ETGE → ETAE) would dramatically diminish its binding affinity. The flanking P4 and P5 subpockets are hydrophobic and tyrosine-rich regions that assist in substrate binding mainly by engaging in hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions. The P6 subpocket, which has drawn researchers’ attention only in recent years, plays an essential role in the interaction between Keap1 and the DLGex motif of Nrf2.

    3. Currently Reported Substrates of Keap1

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As Nrf2 has become a well-defined substrate of Keap1 with a high binding affinity, we will refer to Nrf2 as the “canonical substrate” in this section for convenience. Other substrates will be collectively referred to as the “noncanonical substrates” because they were identified later than Nrf2 and most of them have remained uncharacterized in terms of their interaction with Keap1 (Table 1, Supporting Information, Figure S1).
    Table 1. Currently Validated Substrates of Keap1

    NestinNeuron development1406-DGESDGFADEEESGEEGEED-1425Not known  (51)

    IKBKBRegulation of IKK/NF-κB signaling31-RWHNQETGEQIAIKQCRQEL-50Not knownYesProteasomal or autophagic degradation(25,27,54−60)

    a

    Readers are encouraged to refer to references listed in the table for more information about the function of substrates.

    3.1. Nrf2 as the Canonical Substrate of Keap1

    The Nrf2 protein comprises five Neh domains, namely, Neh1 to Neh5, among which the N-terminal Neh2 domain is responsible for the interaction of Nrf2 with Keap1.(41,42) The Neh2 domain comprises a central α-helix, which harbors seven lysine residues that act as potential ubiquitin acceptors, and two flanking Keap1-binding motifs: the DLGex motif and the ETGE motif (Figure 3A).(39,43,44)
    The Nrf2 ETGE motif (77-DEETGE-82) adopts a tight β-hairpin conformation that is stabilized by multiple intramolecular hydrogen bonds (Figure 3B).(44) When this motif binds the Kelch domain, the carboxyl side chains of two critical glutamate residues, Glu79 and Glu82, occupy the P1 and P2 subpockets, respectively, where they engage in strong salt-bridge and hydrogen-bond interactions with arginine and serine residues (Figure 3D).(21,34,40,44) In addition, the scaffold of the ETGE motif peptide is further stabilized by hydrogen-bond interactions occurring in the P3, P4, and P5 subpockets (Figure 3D). This extensive intermolecular interaction network affords the ETGE motif a very high binding affinity. The association constant (or the Ka value) was measured as 1 × 108 to 2 × 108 M–1.(39,43,45)
    In contrast, the DLGex motif exhibits some variations in its mode of binding. The full-length DLGex motif forms a very distinct and complicated U-shaped structure maintained by a large number of intramolecular hydrogen bonds (Figure 3C).(39) Although this motif also relies on charge-complementary interactions with the P1, P2 subpockets to bind the Kelch domain, its two aspartate residues (Asp27 and Asp29), which have shorter carboxyl side chains than that of glutamate residues, do not reach into the pocket deeply enough to engage in multiple interactions (Figure 3E). Moreover, interactions between the peptide scaffold and the P4 and P5 subpockets are also diminished (Figure 3E). Interestingly, the DLGex motif was found to take advantage of the P6 subpocket, which is not utilized by the ETGE motif. The side-chain amino group of Gln26 engages in hydrogen bonds with the imidazole group of His436 and the main-chain carbonyl group of Gly433 in the P6 subpocket (Figure 3E). In addition, the side-chain carbonyl group of Gln26 engages in another hydrogen bond with Arg380 of the P2 subpocket (Figure 3E). Perhaps due to its less extensive interactions with the P1, P2, P4, and P5 subpockets, the binding affinity of the DLGex motif is 2 orders of magnitude weaker (Ka = 1 × 106 to 2 × 106 M–1) than that of the ETGE motif.(39,43) In addition, the DLGex motif engages in more dynamic interactions with Keap1 that features fast association and dissociation rates.(39)
    To describe the mechanism by which Keap1 captures and regulates Nrf2, two theoretical models have been proposed: the “hinge-and-latch” model(46) and the “conformation cycling” model.(47,48) Both models agree that Keap1 captures Nrf2 through a “two-site binding” mode: two molecules of Keap1 in a homodimer capture one molecule of Nrf2 via both the DLGex motif and the ETGE motif. According to the “hinge-and-latch” model, the high-affinity ETGE motif serves as a “hinge” that firmly anchors Nrf2 to one Kelch domain of the Keap1 dimer, while the low-affinity DLGex motif acts as a “latch” that assists Nrf2 in binding the other Kelch domain. Both models also agree that the fast-on/fast-off nature of the Keap1-DLGex binding gives rise to two potential conformations of the Keap1-Nrf2 complex, “closed” and “open” conformations (Figure 4), and that only the “closed” conformation triggers the ubiquitination of Nrf2 under basal conditions. However, these two models differ in their description of molecular events in the induced state. The “hinge-and-latch” model suggests that the DLGex motif, due to the dynamic nature of its binding, is released from the Kelch domain when Keap1 is modified by oxidants or electrophiles; thus, the “closed” conformation is disrupted and Nrf2 ubiquitination is inhibited. However, evidence in support of dissociation of the DLGex motif is still lacking. On the other hand, the “conformation cycling” model instead suggests that the chemical modification of Keap1 hardly affects binding of the DLGex motif but actually produces a dysfunctional “closed” conformation of the Keap1-Nrf2 complex in which Nrf2 ubiquitination is hampered, possibly due to the conformational change in Keap1. The specific mechanism that governs Keap1-Nrf2 binding remains to be determined. However, regardless of how Nrf2 ubiquitination is inhibited in the induced state, Keap1 proteins are occupied by trapped Nrf2, and de novo synthesized Nrf2 proteins do finally manage to enter the nucleus, where they activate gene transcription.
    Studies on Nrf2, the canonical substrate of Keap1, have provided us with valuable insights into how Keap1 recognizes its substrates and how the substrate ubiquitination is coupled to redox sensing. More importantly, these valuable insights have laid a solid foundation for the identification and study of noncanonical substrate proteins of Keap1.

    3.2. Emerging Noncanonical Substrates of Keap1

    3.2.1. Physical Interactions between Keap1 and Noncanonical Substrates

    Over the most recent decade, a group of proteins that interact with the Keap1 Kelch domain have been identified by proteomic studies.(24−27) More importantly, most of these proteins also contain the ETGE(-like) or DLGex(-like) motifs found in Nrf2 (Table 1). Thus, a critical question is whether these proteins bind the Keap1 Kelch domain in a way similar to that of Nrf2.
    Until now, the physical interaction between Keap1 and the noncanonical substrates has been best illustrated by the case of p62/SQSTM1. Crosstalk between p62 and the Nrf2-ARE pathway was first identified by a high-throughput screen of the human cDNA library for genetic Nrf2 activators, which identified p62 as a “hit gene”.(73) Soon after, the mechanism behind this crosstalk was revealed: p62 competitively binds the Keap1 Kelch domain through a Keap1-interacting region (KIR) to disrupt the Keap1-Nrf2 system.(75) The KIR of human p62 contains an ETGE-like motif (347-DPSTGE-352, referred to as the STGE motif), which has been proven to be indispensable for Keap1 binding.(75) Interestingly, cocrystal structure studies have revealed that the p62 STGE motif not only adopts a β-turn conformation similar to that of the Nrf2 ETGE motif but also binds the Keap1 Kelch domain in a way similar to that of the Nrf2 ETGE motif (Figure 5A).(75) The major difference between the p62 STGE motif and the Nrf2 ETGE motif is that the former fails to fully exploit the P1 subpocket. The side chain of Ser349, which is too short to reach the core of the P1 subpocket, makes only distant contact with Arg415 (Figure 5D). Intriguingly, p62 undergoes mTORC1-dependent phosphorylation at its Ser349 site during the autophagic clearance process.(78) This modification not only elongates the side chain of Ser349 but also adds negative charges to it (Figure 5B). Therefore, phosphorylated Ser439 can be deeply inserted into the P1 subpocket, where it engages in extensive electrostatic interactions with Arg415, Arg483, and Ser508 (Figure 5D).(37,78) Thus, binding of the Ser349-phosphorylated p62 STGE motif highly resembles that of the Nrf2 ETGE motif.
    Another good example in support of the similarity between Nrf2 and noncanonical substrates in terms of Keap1 binding is the Keap1-ProTα complex. ProTα, encoded by the PTMA gene, contains a different ETGE-like motif (41-NEENGE-46, referred to as the ENGE motif) that mediates its interaction with the Keap1 Kelch domain (Figure 5C).(82−85) Although substitution of the Asp and Thr residues (DEETGE, Nrf2) with two Asn residues (NEENGE, ProTα) might have impaired the stability of the β-turn conformation, the intermolecular interaction network between Keap1 and ProTα was largely unaffected and remained similar to that between Keap1 and the Nrf2 ETGE motif (Figure 5E).(85) However, the disordered nature of ProTα plus unfavorable substitution with Asn residues made it difficult for ProTα to adopt a preformed β-turn conformation at the ENGE motif region, which brings it a major energetic penalty to overcome the decrease in entropy caused by a binding-induced conformation change. Therefore, ProTα is still far less potent than Nrf2 (Table 1).
    In addition, virtual docking analysis has predicted that the ETGE motif of IKKβ (34-NQETGE-39), which adopts a β-turn conformation (Supporting Information, Figure S2),(87) also occupied the substrate-binding pocket in a way similar to that of the Nrf2 ETGE motif.(58) Besides, residue-substitution studies on the Nrf2 ETGE motif,(88) the p62 STGE motif,(88) and the ProTα ENGE motif(83,88) have shown that the Keap1 Kelch domain accepts many variants of the ETGE motifs, among which the proline-substituted ETGE motif (xPETGE) is the most favorable. Indeed, some validated noncanonical substrates, such as p62 (DPSTGE), DPP3 (NPETGE), and AMER1 (SPETGE), contain this special type of ETGE motif. Moreover, all the validated noncanonical substrates listed in Table 1 have been found to activate the Nrf2-ARE pathway by competitively binding the Keap1 Kelch domain. Therefore, on the basis of these data, we believe that Nrf2 and the noncanonical substrates of Keap1, at least those with ETGE(-like) motifs, very likely share similar binding modes.

    3.2.2. Functional Interactions between Keap1 and Its Noncanonical Substrates

    The physical Keap1-substrate interaction has an impact on the biological functions of both proteins. For Keap1, the most obvious impact is the loosening of its tight control of Nrf2 because of the competitive binding of noncanonical substrates. Such a scenario is most likely to occur in Nrf2high cancers without the genetic alteration of either Nrf2-coding or Keap1-coding genes.(24) In addition, the Keap1-p62 interaction contributes to Keap1 protein turnover. The p62 protein has been established as a cargo receptor for selective autophagy, as p62 binds the polyubiquitin chains of unwanted protein cargos to sequester them into autophagosomes.(89) However, due to its strong interaction with Keap1, cargo-associated p62 also sequesters Keap1 into early autophagosomes and promotes its degradation through the autophagy-lysosome pathway.(75,76,78,90) The p62-mediated degradation of Keap1 further diminished Keap1’s control of Nrf2. Moreover, the wide subcellular distribution of Keap1 is highly reliant on its physical interaction with noncanonical substrates. For example, the interaction of Keap1 with PGAM5 relocates Keap1 from the cytosol to the outer mitochondrial membrane,(68,69,71) enriching the mitochondria-associated pool of Keap1. In addition, by interacting with MCM3, Keap1 is recruited to the MCM2–7 complex and might thereby be loaded onto chromatin during the genome replication process.(26) For substrates, the most important impact of physical interaction with Keap1 is substrate ubiquitination by the CRL3 complex. Until now, the noncanonical substrates that have been reported to undergo Keap1-dependent ubiquitination are p62, IKKβ, PGAM5, PALB2, and MCM3, all of which perform functions distinct from those of Nrf2 (Table 1). As is the case for Nrf2, ubiquitination of PGAM5 and IKKβ leads to their degradation and thus inhibits their functions.(54,67,68) However, interestingly, ubiquitination of PALB2 at Lys20/25/30 sites, which reside within an N-terminal coiled-coil recognized by BRCA1,(91−93) hardly affects the stability of PALB2 but rather hampers its interaction with BRCA1 and thus its ability to initiate homologous recombination (HR) repair in response to DNA damage.(65) This ubiquitination is crucial for suppression of the HR-dependent DNA repair machinery in G1 phase of the cell cycle.(65) Another example of the effect of Keap1-dependent ubiquitination on PPIs comes in the form of p62. Keap1-mediated ubiquitination of p62 at the Lys420 site promotes the self-oligomerization of p62 and therefore strengthens its ability to sequester and sort out polyubiquitinated cargos.(94,95) Notably, p62 proteins exist in a dimer–monomer equilibrium within cells,(96,97) and only dimeric p62 is ubiquitinated by the Keap1-based CRL3 complex.(94) However, the ubiquitination of MCM3 affects neither protein stability nor assembly of the MCM2–7 complex.(26) The specific biological significance of MCM3 ubiquitination remains to be elucidated. In addition to promoting substrate ubiquitination, the physical interaction with Keap1 alone affects functions of its substrates. For example, the Keap1-PGAM5 interaction allows Keap1 to tether PGAM5 to the outer mitochondrial membrane, thus preventing its translocation to the inner membrane, where PGAM5 was found to dephosphorylate AIFM1 and initiate oxeiptosis.(71,98) Additionally, overexpression of the Keap1 Kelch domain, which is unable to promote substrate ubiquitination due to the absence of the BTB domain, was still sufficient to inhibit TNFα-induced activation of the NF-κB pathway, possibly by preventing the phosphorylation of IKKβ.(60)

    3.3. Canonical and Noncanonical Pools of Keap1 within Cells

    Given that both Nrf2 and noncanonical substrates can interact with Keap1, we divide the whole pool of Keap1 within cells into two major portions based on the substrates that are sequestered (Figure 6). One part of the pool, referred to as the canonical pool, binds Nrf2 with a high binding affinity, while the other part, referred to as the noncanonical pool, binds noncanonical substrates with a relatively lower affinity. These two pools of Keap1 are presumed to be in equilibrium, exchanging components with each other through a balancing pool (BLP). In the BLP, substrates from the noncanonical pool competitively bind the Keap1-Nrf2 complex and possibly displace the low-affinity DLGex motif of Nrf2 with their more stable ETGE(-like) motifs, forming a ternary complex containing Keap1, Nrf2, and a substrate competitor.
    From the perspective of functional interactions, the interaction of Keap1 with various substrates leads to specialization of its function. The Keap1 in the canonical pool is responsible for controlling the activity of Nrf2 under both basal and stressed conditions, due to which Keap1 couples redox sensing with the antioxidant response, biotransformation and detoxification, inflammation resolution, etc. On the other hand, Keap1 in the noncanonical pool is isolated from Nrf2 and thus interacts with other substrates, thereby performing Nrf2-independent functions, such as regulating p62-dependent autophagy, inhibiting IKKβ-mediated NF-κB activation, and suppressing PALB2-mediated HR repair in cells at G1 phase, etc. (Figure 6).

    4. Current Development of Direct Keap1-Nrf2 PPI Small-Molecule Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Compared with classic PPI targets, the Keap1-Nrf2 PPI interface is quite unique. First, the traditional PPI interface is always larger than 1000 Å2,(99) but the Keap1-Nrf2 PPI surface is more like a protein-small molecule interface and approximately 500–800 Å2 in area.(21) Second, the Keap1 Kelch domain can be artificially subdivided into six subpockets with well-defined hot-spot features as described above in section 2. These characteristics provide the possibility for small molecules to occupy the substrate-binding pocket of the Keap1 Kelch domain.
    The first small-molecule inhibitor of the Keap1-Nrf2 PPI, which bears a 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline core, was discovered from a high-throughput screen (HTS) of the NIH MLPCN library by Hu et al. in 2013.(100) After that, a series of PPI inhibitors with various structural skeletons emerged. Among them, two series of compounds have attracted a great deal of attention and interest from medicinal chemists: (i) inhibitors with a 1,4-diaminonaphthalene core, which have undergone the most comprehensive structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies to date, and (ii) inhibitors with a 3-phenylpropanoic acid core, which have achieved the highest potency in both cell-free and cell-based assays among all reported inhibitors. Importantly, the compounds in these two categories were validated as “true” inhibitors by a recent side-by-side assessment of reported Keap1–Nrf2 PPI inhibitors, while many other compounds with distinct skeletons turned out to be “fake” inhibitors.(101) Thus, in this section, we mainly focus on the development of these two series of inhibitors to demonstrate the current “ETGE”-based strategy in drug development and provide an update of the most recent advances regarding these inhibitors. As some outstanding reviews have already provided a comprehensive introduction to the history of drug development in this field,(7,20,21,102) readers are encouraged to refer to these papers for more information about other series of inhibitors.

    4.1. Development of PPI Inhibitors with a 1,4-Diaminonaphthalene Core

    The development of 1,4-diaminonaphthalene-bearing compounds serves as a classic example in the Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitor field and has provided many valuable insights into SAR for future drug development. Silvian and her group discovered the first Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitor of this type (Figure 7, compound 1) by screening the Evotec Lead Discovery library using the two-dimensional fluorescence intensity distribution analysis (2D-FIDA) in 2013.(103) The hit compound 1 showed an IC50 of 2.7 μM in the 2D-FIDA assay and activated the Nrf2-ARE pathway in a cell-based ARE-luciferase reporter assay. The cocrystal structure of the Keap1-compound 1 complex showed that compound 1 mainly occupied the P3, P4, and P5 subpockets (Figure 8A). The naphthalene ring of compound 1 fits into the P3 subpocket, where it formed a cation−π interaction with the guanidine group of Arg415 and hydrophobic contacts with the side chains of both Arg415 and Ala556. The two flanking methoxy-substituted phenyl rings in compound 1 made hydrophobic contacts with Tyr525 in the P4 subpocket and Phe577, Tyr572, and Try334 in the P5 subpocket. The two sulfamide linkers in compound 1 were stabilized by hydrogen bonds with Ser508 in the P1 subpocket and Ser602 in the P3 subpocket, respectively. The next year, You’s group made great progress in this field. They noticed that the positively charged P1 and P2 subpockets, which provide the major binding energy in the Keap1-Nrf2 ETGE interaction, were nearly neglected by compound 1.(38) On the basis of the distance between the sulfamide group and the unoccupied subpockets, they added two carboxylic acid side chains to the sulfamide linkers to mimic Glu79 and Glu82 of the Nrf2 ETGE motif and thus generated compound 2, which occupied all five subpockets as the Nrf2 ETGE motif does.(38) Compound 2 presented a nanomolar binding affinity in both bioluminescence imaging (BLI) (Kd = 3.59 nM) and fluorescence polarization (FP) (IC50 = 28.6 nM) assays. Such dramatic improvement in binding affinity suggested the importance of the P1 and P2 subpockets in the rational design of Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors.
    However, the incorporation of two carboxylic acid groups, plus the symmetric nature of the structure, potentially impaired the membrane permeability and bioavailability of target compounds.(104) To improve its physicochemical and drug-like properties, two strategies were currently used to optimize lead compound 2. The first strategy was to reduce or replace unfavorable polar substituents with more favorable bioisosteres without seriously damaging the structural symmetry. For example, Moore’s group focused on unfavorable carboxylic acid side chains and found that replacing the diacetate moiety with a diacetamide-substituted analog, as exhibited by compound 3, improved the drug-like properties without disrupting interactions within the P1 and P2 subpockets (Figure 8B).(105) Similar work has also been conducted by You’s group, which first replaced the p-methoxy groups of the flanking phenyl rings with p-acetamide (compound 4) and then substituted the diacetate moiety with bioisosteric tetrazole groups to obtain a more drug-like compound 5 with even better inhibitory potency than compound 2.(106,107) Another strategy used was to break the structural symmetry. Crystals of symmetrical molecules tend to have higher lattice energy and poorer solubility than the crystals of less symmetrical molecules with similar structures.(108) The first example of this strategy comes from RA839 (compound 6), which was independently discovered by Schmoll’s group in a drug screening program.(109) Compared with compound 2, the asymmetrical compound 6 has just a single carboxylic acid side chain and does not exploit the P2 and P4 subpockets (Figure 8C). However, its inhibitory potency was still maintained within the nanomolar range,(109) indicating that molecular symmetry of ligands was not necessarily required for Keap1 binding. In 2019, You’s group reported another example of this strategy. By incorporating α-proline into the naphthalene sulfonamide scaffold, they obtained compound 7, a potent Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitor with an asymmetrical structure.(104) Importantly, intraperitoneal administration of compound 7 significantly alleviated acetaminophen-induced hepatotoxicity in mice through activation of the Nrf2-ARE pathway, which validated the improvement in physicochemical and drug-like properties.(104)
    In addition to potential poor physicochemical and drug-like properties, Moore’s group has suggested another concern regarding naphthalene-based inhibitors: their naphthalene scaffold might be oxidatively metabolized to quinone-type reactive metabolites and thus become toxic and mutagenic.(110) To improve metabolic stability, Moore’s group found that 1,4-substituted isoquinoline skeleton, as demonstrated by compound 8, represented an alternative to the naphthalene scaffold.(110) In 2019, Moore’s group reported that replacement of a carboxymethyl group at the 4-position of compound 8 with a fluoroalkyl group, which led to compound 9, afforded a further improvement in metabolic stability.(111)

    4.2. Development of PPI Inhibitors with a 3-Phenylpropanoic Acid Core

    While the 1,4-diaminonaphthalene-bearing PPI inhibitors were developed mainly by medicinal chemists in academia, 3-phenylpropanoic acid-bearing PPI inhibitors resulted from a joint effort between Astex Pharmaceuticals and GlaxoSmithKline Pharmaceuticals. In 2016, using fragment-based drug discovery, Davies and co-workers developed KI-696 as a nanomolar Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitor with drug-like physicochemical properties.(112) Impressively, KI-696 was reported to have a nanomolar EC50 of 12 nM in a cell-based NQO1 enzymatic activity assay.(112) In 2019, they presented a detailed account of the medicinal chemistry campaign leading to KI-696.(113)
    Development of KI-696 began with a crystallographic screen of approximately 330 fragments which finally identified three fragments that occupy three hot-spots, referred to as the “acid”, “planar acceptor”, and “sulfonamide” subpockets, in the substrate-binding pocket of the Keap1 Kelch domain (Figure 9A).(112,113) The carboxylic acid side chain of fragment 1 is inserted into the “acid” or P1 subpocket, where it forms hydrogen-bond interactions with Arg483 and Ser508 (Figure 9B). In addition, the phenyl ring of fragment 1 occupies the P3 subpocket by making hydrophobic contacts with Ala556 (Figure 9B). Fragment 2 clusters within the “planar” subpocket, where it forms a π–π stacking interaction with Tyr525 and two hydrogen bonds with Ser555 and Gln530 in the P4 subpocket (Figure 9C). Fragment 3 occupies the “sulfonamide” or P3 subpocket by engaging in a hydrogen bond with Ser602 (Figure 9D). Notably, the interaction patterns of these three fragments in the P1, P3, and P4 subpockets highly resemble those made by the Nrf2 ETGE motif.
    To design a compound that could recapitulate these interaction patterns, fragment 1 was chosen as the scaffold to which functionalities to reach the “planar acceptor” and “sulfonamide” subpockets could be properly attached. To exploit the “planar acceptor” subpocket, they hypothesized that a fused bicyclic heterocycle with a double hydrogen-bond acceptor motif would be favorable for this site.(113) Indeed, when a methyl benzotriazole functional group was attached to the benzylic position of fragment 1, compound 11 occupied the “planar acceptor” subpocket exactly as fragment 2 did and presented a measurable IC50 of 47 μM in the FP assay (Figure 10). To further exploit the “sulfonamide” subpocket on the basis of compound 11, they first ensured that the substituent adopted a proper orientation toward the “sulfonamide” subpocket through growth ortho to the chloro substituent (compound 12) and then attached a methyl sulfonamide functional group to the methylene carbon (compound 13) to allow the sulfonamide oxygen to accept a hydrogen bond from Ser602 and finally replaced the sulfonyl methyl group with a phenyl group (compound 14) to generate π–π stacking and lipophilic interactions with Tyr334.(113) To date, compound 14 has recapitulated all the interaction patterns made by the three fragments and showed a dramatically enhanced IC50 of 0.27 μM in the FP assay. Further structural optimization of compound 14 included the replacement of the chloro-substituent with a methyl group, the introduction of a methoxy group to the benzotriazole 7-position, cyclization of the phenyl sulfonamide, and addition of a methyl group to the position α to the oxathiazepine oxygen, which finally led to KI-696. Notably, these structural operations were carried out mainly for conformational optimization to ensure that KI-696 adopted a favorable preorganized conformation to fit the substrate-binding pocket of the Keap1 Kelch domain.
    Interestingly, the importance of a preorganized conformation to a high binding affinity is also reflected in the Keap1–substrate interaction. For Nrf2, the Thr residue of its ETGE motif is involved in a dynamic intramolecular hydrogen-bond network that stabilizes the β-turn conformation.(84) Mutation of Thr to Ser, which still retains the side-chain hydroxyl group, minimally disrupted the binding affinity.(40,83) This accounts for the existence of the ESGE motif among Keap1’s substrates, such as PGAM5 (NVESGE) and Nestin (EEESGE). However, phosphorylation of Thr severely hampered binding,(40) indicating that a long and charged side chain in this position is unfavorable. Likewise, the substitution of Thr to Asn, as is the case for the ProTα ENGE motif, has a significant impact on the free-state conformation by disrupting the intramolecular hydrogen-bond network, making it difficult for ProTα to adopt a preformed local structure.(84) The reverse mutation of Asn back to Thr or Ser enhanced the Keap1-ProTα interaction.(83) In addition, mutation of Glu to Pro (EENGE → PENGE), a β-turn-forming residue, also enhanced the binding affinity of ProTα.(83) It is not surprising that a number of noncanonical substrates harbor proline residues in their ETGE(-like) motifs to help them better interact with Keap1 (Table 1). All of the evidence highlights the importance of a preformed structure to increase binding affinity. Therefore, a conformation-based strategy for structural optimization could be applied in the future development of high-potency Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors.

    5. Concerns for the Target Selectivity of Current Keap1-Nrf2 PPI Small-Molecule Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Notably, to achieve Nrf2 activation, Keap1 proteins in the canonical pool must be inhibited. However, current Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors seem to be unable to distinguish the canonical pool and the noncanonical pool for the following reasons: (i) as described above in section 4, current Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors were designed largely based on the “ETGE” strategy in which small molecules are optimized to mimic the Nrf2 ETGE motif to increase binding affinity, and their inhibitory potency was evaluated in assays developed based on the Keap1-Nrf2 ETGE interaction, such as the FP assay; (ii) the ETGE(-like) motifs are widely distributed among noncanonical substrates (Table 1); and (iii) noncanonical substrates with an ETGE(-like) motif very likely bind Keap1 in a way similar to that of the Nrf2 ETGE motif, as discussed in section 3. Indeed, compound 1 and compound 10 have been observed to prevent both the Nrf2 ETGE motif and the Ser349-phosphorylated p62 STGE motif from binding the Keap1 Kelch domain.(114,115) In addition, compounds 1 and 2 were reported to promote mitochondrial respiration and induce mitophagy, while covalent Nrf2 activators, including sulforaphane and dimethyl fumarate, were unable to induce such a response even though they activated the Nrf2 pathway as compounds 1 and 2 did.(116,117) Such potential Nrf2-independent effects of compounds 1 and 2 might result from the inhibition of interactions between Keap1 and noncanonical substrates, such as PGAM5, which plays an essential role in mitophagy regulation and mitochondrial quality control.
    If current small-molecule Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors indeed have an inherent defect in their target selectivity, it remains difficult to judge whether this defect is good or bad for further development. The advantage is that such unselective inhibitory actions might bring unexpected synergistic cytoprotection effects. For example, mitophagy is a critical elimination mechanism in which dysfunctional mitochondria are removed and cells are protected from mitochondria-mediated apoptosis during tissue inflammation.(118) Since PPI inhibitors have been observed to induce both Nrf2 activation and mitophagy, this “dual-pathway” mechanism might afford better protection to stressed cells under pathological conditions.(119) However, the disadvantage of such a defect in target selectivity is also obvious as these potential off-target actions are beyond the framework of Nrf2-based therapies. For example, as both physical and functional interactions mediate Keap1’s suppression of IKKβ, IKKβ seems to be sensitive to the inhibition of Keap1. It has been observed that both small interfering RNA (siRNA)-mediated and covalent modification-mediated inhibition of Keap1 led to an increased level of activated IKKβ and downstream activation of the NF-κB pathway in cells and animals.(60,120) It is likely that competitive binding-mediated inhibition of Keap1 by PPI inhibitors would generate a similar proinflammatory effect, which potentially antagonizes their anti-inflammatory effect resulting from Nrf2 activation. Another concern is the Keap1-PALB2 interaction, which plays an essential role in coordinating the HR-mediated DNA damage repair machinery within the cell cycle.(65) Unfortunately, human PALB2 contains an ETGE motif (88-LDEETGE-94) 100% identical to that of Nrf2 (76-LDEETGE-82), which means its interaction with Keap1 is very likely to be inhibited by current PPI inhibitors, especially those that exhibit high potency in “ETGE”-based assays. This potential off-target action might increase the mutagenesis risk in long-term drug administration. To address these concerns, a systemic investigation of this topic is urgently needed.

    6. Future Perspectives for the Development of Selective Keap1-Nrf2 PPI Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    While the ETGE motif is a feature shared among Nrf2 and noncanonical Keap1 substrates, the DLGex motif remains unique to Nrf2 and has no equivalent among currently reported noncanonical substrates except for iASPP, which relies on a variant DLT motif to bind Keap1.(53) In addition, according to both the “hinge-and-latch” model and the “conformation cycling” model, inhibiting the Keap1-Nrf2 DLGex interaction is sufficient to induce activation of the Nrf2-ARE pathway. Thus, targeting the Keap1-Nrf2 DLGex interaction, or the “DLGex”-based strategy, might have a large advantage over the current “ETGE”-based strategy for the development of selective Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors.
    Investigation into the Keap1-Nrf2 ETGE interaction and the Keap1-Nrf2 DLGex interaction has indicated that the major difference between the two lies in the P6 subpocket. In this regard, incorporation of the P6 subpocket into rational drug design might afford PPI inhibitors better selectivity. The P6 subpocket, which is flat and open, harbors a slight hollow (or the H site) and a narrow groove (or the G site) on its upper edge (Figure 11A). The H site contains two potential hydrogen-bond-accepting functional groups on its surface: the imidazole group of His436 and the backbone carbonyl group of Gly433 (Figure 11A). The G site, which features negatively charged Asp389 as a functional group, is adjacent to the upper surface of the P2 subpocket and thus sensitive to conformational change in the P2 subpocket. For example, if the substrate-binding pocket was occupied by the Nrf2 DLGex motif, the guanidine group of Arg380 would move laterally toward Gln26 to generate a hydrogen bond, and the entrance of the G site would be blocked (Figure 11B). However, if the pocket was occupied by the Nrf2 ETGE motif, the side chain of Arg380 would be drawn downward by Glu82, leaving the G site open for exploitation (Figure 11B). In addition to the H site, the opening of the G site provides another anchoring spot to increase both the inhibitory potency and the selectivity of small molecules. On the other hand, to evaluate the inhibitory potency of selective Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors, the Keap1-DLGex interaction must be incorporated into the assay system. An ideal compound should have the ability to exclude the Nrf2 DLGex motif from binding but still cannot compete with the high-affinity Nrf2 ETGE motif. Interestingly, compound 1 has been observed to show stronger inhibitory potency against the Nrf2 DLGex motif than against the Nrf2 ETGE motif in an in vitro pull-down assay.(115) Perhaps there may already be lead compounds of this type hidden in the pool of current Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors that we could identify simply by re-evaluating their inhibitory potency in DLGex-based assay systems.

    7. Summary and Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Currently, the design and evaluation of small-molecule Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors are mainly based on the “ETGE” strategy. However, Nrf2 and emerging noncanonical substrates contain similar ETGE motifs and utilize a similar mode of interaction with the Keap1 Kelch domain, which suggests that current PPI inhibitors might have potential off-target actions. Indeed, this growing concern has been partially supported by some experiments. However, owing to the lack of systemic investigation into this topic, how off-target actions would impact the future development of Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors is still unclear. Great efforts are needed to answer this question, as many noncanonical substrates, such as AMER1, FAM129B, DPP3, and MCM3, remain largely uncharacterized in terms of both their physical and functional interactions with Keap1. On the other hand, from the perspective of Nrf2-based therapy, a selective Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitor would always be preferred. To develop such a molecule, we may need to shift from the current “ETGE”-based strategy to the “DLGex”-based strategy, which aims to inhibit the Keap1-Nrf2 DLGex interaction and highlights the P6 subpocket in drug design. In short, the future of Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors is promising, but the journey remains long.

    ARTICLE SECTIONS

    This article references 120 other publications.

    1. 1
      Cuadrado, A.; Manda, G.; Hassan, A.; Alcaraz, M. J.; Barbas, C.; Daiber, A.; Ghezzi, P.; Leon, R.; Lopez, M. G.; Oliva, B.; Pajares, M.; Rojo, A. I.; Robledinos-Anton, N.; Valverde, A. M.; Guney, E.; Schmidt, H. Transcription Factor Nrf2 as a Therapeutic Target for Chronic Diseases: A Systems Medicine Approach. Pharmacol. Rev. 2018, 70, 348– 383,  DOI: 10.1124/pr.117.014753
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Transcription factor NRF2 as a therapeutic target for chronic diseases: a systems medicine approach
      Cuadrado, Antonio; Manda, Gina; Hassan, Ahmed; Alcaraz, Maria Jose; Barbas, Coral; Daiber, Andreas; Ghezzi, Pietro; Leon, Rafael; Lopez, Manuela G.; Oliva, Baldo; Pajares, Marta; Rojo, Ana I.; Robledinos-Anton, Natalia; Valverde, Angela M.; Guney, Emre; Schmidt, Harald H. H. W.
      Pharmacological Reviews (2018), 70 (2), 348-383CODEN: PAREAQ; ISSN:1521-0081. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      Systems medicine has a mechanism-based rather than a symptom- or organ-based approach to disease and identifies therapeutic targets in a nonhypothesis-driven manner. In this work, we apply this to transcription factor nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2 (NRF2) by cross-validating its position in a protein-protein interaction network (the NRF2 interactome) functionally linked to cytoprotection in low-grade stress, chronic inflammation, metabolic alterations, and reactive oxygen species formation. Multiscale network anal. of these mol. profiles suggests alterations of NRF2 expression and activity as a common mechanism in a subnetwork of diseases (the NRF2 diseasome). This network joins apparently heterogeneous phenotypes such as autoimmune, respiratory, digestive, cardiovascular, metabolic, and neurodegenerative diseases, along with cancer. Importantly, this approach matches and confirms in silico several applications for NRF2-modulating drugs validated in vivo at different phases of clin. development. Pharmacol., their profile is as diverse as electrophilic di-Me fumarate, synthetic triterpenoids like bardoxolone Me and sulforaphane, protein-protein or DNA-protein interaction inhibitors, and even registered drugs such as metformin and statins, which activate NRF2 and may be repurposed for indications within the NRF2 cluster of disease phenotypes. Thus, NRF2 represents one of the first targets fully embraced by classic and systems medicine approaches to facilitate both drug development and drug repurposing by focusing on a set of disease phenotypes that appear to be mechanistically linked. The resulting NRF2 drugome may therefore rapidly advance several surprising clin. options for this subset of chronic diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXkvVKnsLw%253D&md5=e2644f0d324522d593988853ba694e15
    2. 2
      Franceschi, C.; Garagnani, P.; Parini, P.; Giuliani, C.; Santoro, A. Inflammaging: A New Immune-Metabolic Viewpoint for Age-Related Diseases. Nat. Rev. Endocrinol. 2018, 14, 576– 590,  DOI: 10.1038/s41574-018-0059-4
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Inflammaging: a new immune-metabolic viewpoint for age-related diseases
      Franceschi, Claudio; Garagnani, Paolo; Parini, Paolo; Giuliani, Cristina; Santoro, Aurelia
      Nature Reviews Endocrinology (2018), 14 (10), 576-590CODEN: NREABD; ISSN:1759-5029. (Nature Research)
      A review. Ageing and age-related diseases share some basic mechanistic pillars that largely converge on inflammation. During ageing, chronic, sterile, low-grade inflammation - called inflammaging - develops, which contributes to the pathogenesis of age-related diseases. From an evolutionary perspective, a variety of stimuli sustain inflammaging, including pathogens (non-self), endogenous cell debris and misplaced mols. (self) and nutrients and gut microbiota (quasi-self). A limited no. of receptors, whose degeneracy allows them to recognize many signals and to activate the innate immune responses, sense these stimuli. In this situation, metaflammation (the metabolic inflammation accompanying metabolic diseases) is thought to be the form of chronic inflammation that is driven by nutrient excess or overnutrition; metaflammation is characterized by the same mechanisms underpinning inflammaging. The gut microbiota has a central role in both metaflammation and inflammaging owing to its ability to release inflammatory products, contribute to circadian rhythms and crosstalk with other organs and systems. We argue that chronic diseases are not only the result of ageing and inflammaging; these diseases also accelerate the ageing process and can be considered a manifestation of accelerated ageing. Finally, we propose the use of new biomarkers (DNA methylation, glycomics, metabolomics and lipidomics) that are capable of assessing biol. vs. chronol. age in metabolic diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtl2gtL7N&md5=d3d58a5ba98427c81055fb6ed39c6b14
    3. 3
      Yamamoto, M.; Kensler, T. W.; Motohashi, H. The Keap1-Nrf2 System: A Thiol-Based Sensor-Effector Apparatus for Maintaining Redox Homeostasis. Physiol. Rev. 2018, 98, 1169– 1203,  DOI: 10.1152/physrev.00023.2017
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      The KEAP1-NRF2 system: a thiol-based sensor-effector apparatus for maintaining redox homeostasis
      Yamamoto, Masayuki; Kensler, Thomas W.; Motohashi, Hozumi
      Physiological Reviews (2018), 98 (3), 1169-1203CODEN: PHREA7; ISSN:1522-1210. (American Physiological Society)
      A review. The Kelch-like ECH-assocd. protein 1-NF-E2-related factor 2 (KEAP1-NRF2) system forms the major node of cellular and organismal defense against oxidative and electrophilic stresses of both exogenous and endogenous origins. KEAP1 acts as a cysteine thiol-rich sensor of redox insults, whereas NRF2 is a transcription factor that robustly transduces chem. signals to regulate a battery of cytoprotective genes. KEAP1 represses NRF2 activity under quiescent conditions, whereas NRF2 is liberated from KEAP1-mediated repression on exposure to stresses. The rapid inducibility of a response based on a derepression mechanism is an important feature of the KEAP1-NRF2 system. Recent studies have unveiled the complexities of the functional contributions of the KEAP1-NRF2 system and defined its broader involvement in biol. processes, including cell proliferation and differentiation, as well as cytoprotection. In this review, we describe historical milestones in the initial characterization of the KEAP1-NRF2 system and provide a comprehensive overview of the mol. mechanisms governing the functions of KEAP1 and NRF2, as well as their roles in physiol. and pathol. We also refer to the clin. significance of the KEAP1-NRF2 system as an important prophylactic and therapeutic target for various diseases, particularly aging-related disorders. We believe that controlled harnessing of the KEAP1-NRF2 system is a key to healthy aging and well-being in humans.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXkvFektrc%253D&md5=906947c8ad97c48f60e46bc44103664a
    4. 4
      Battino, M.; Giampieri, F.; Pistollato, F.; Sureda, A.; de Oliveira, M. R.; Pittala, V.; Fallarino, F.; Nabavi, S. F.; Atanasov, A. G.; Nabavi, S. M. Nrf2 as Regulator of Innate Immunity: A Molecular Swiss Army Knife!. Biotechnol. Adv. 2018, 36, 358– 370,  DOI: 10.1016/j.biotechadv.2017.12.012
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Nrf2 as regulator of innate immunity: A molecular Swiss army knife!
      Battino, Maurizio; Giampieri, Francesca; Pistollato, Francesca; Sureda, Antoni; de Oliveira, Marcos Roberto; Pittala, Valeria; Fallarino, Francesca; Nabavi, Seyed Fazel; Atanasov, Atanas Georgiev; Nabavi, Seyed Mohammad
      Biotechnology Advances (2018), 36 (2), 358-370CODEN: BIADDD; ISSN:0734-9750. (Elsevier)
      Organisms are constantly exposed to a broad range of pathol. and stress-inducing agents, allergens and environmental chems. that can induce infections, toxicity or other undesirable reactions. Our immune system has evolved over time in order to efficiently respond to these exogenous insults and maintain homeostasis. In particular, the innate immune system acts as primary barrier to prevent the entrance of invasive agents or allergens. This system is comprised of a diversity of cell types that are rapidly activated by recognition of common structures present in many potential pathogens known as pathogen-assocd. mol. patterns (PAMPs). The nuclear factor erythroid 2 related factor 2 (Nrf2) is a relevant basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor that is essential in the regulation of cell cycle homeostasis, cytoprotection, and innate immunity when cells are under stressful conditions. Although the role of Nrf2 in activating the expression of protective genes - such as antioxidant or anti-inflammatory - is known, its role in innate immunity and immune-related gene expression remains not yet clear. The present review summarizes current knowledge on Nrf2 signaling pathway structure and activity under both physiol. state and upon oxidative stress. In addn., the relation between Nrf2 signaling pathway and the innate immune system is discussed, highlighting the potential therapeutic effects of diverse natural and synthetic compds. as Nrf2 regulators.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXitVCktLnP&md5=e516646dab60025f553abfcabc3498f2
    5. 5
      Hayes, J. D.; Dinkova-Kostova, A. T. The Nrf2 Regulatory Network Provides an Interface between Redox and Intermediary Metabolism. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2014, 39, 199– 218,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tibs.2014.02.002
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      The Nrf2 regulatory network provides an interface between redox and intermediary metabolism
      Hayes, John D.; Dinkova-Kostova, Albena T.
      Trends in Biochemical Sciences (2014), 39 (4), 199-218CODEN: TBSCDB; ISSN:0968-0004. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Nuclear factor-erythroid 2 p45-related factor 2 (Nrf2, also called Nfe2l2) is a transcription factor that regulates the cellular redox status. Nrf2 is controlled through a complex transcriptional/epigenetic and post-translational network that ensures its activity increases during redox perturbation, inflammation, growth factor stimulation and nutrient/energy fluxes, thereby enabling the factor to orchestrate adaptive responses to diverse forms of stress. Besides mediating stress-stimulated induction of antioxidant and detoxification genes, Nrf2 contributes to adaptation by upregulating the repair and degrdn. of damaged macromols., and by modulating intermediary metab. In the latter case, Nrf2 inhibits lipogenesis, supports β-oxidn. of fatty acids, facilitates flux through the pentose phosphate pathway, and increases NADPH regeneration and purine biosynthesis; these observations suggest Nrf2 directs metabolic reprogramming during stress.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXksVWrtLg%253D&md5=790c66c48218229dc5531d24aefaceef
    6. 6
      Cuadrado, A.; Rojo, A. I.; Wells, G.; Hayes, J. D.; Cousin, S. P.; Rumsey, W. L.; Attucks, O. C.; Franklin, S.; Levonen, A. L.; Kensler, T. W.; Dinkova-Kostova, A. T. Therapeutic Targeting of the Nrf2 and Keap1 Partnership in Chronic Diseases. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2019, 18, 295– 317,  DOI: 10.1038/s41573-018-0008-x

      Therapeutic targeting of the NRF2 and KEAP1 partnership in chronic diseases
      Cuadrado, Antonio; Rojo, Ana I.; Wells, Geoffrey; Hayes, John D.; Cousin, Sharon P.; Rumsey, William L.; Attucks, Otis C.; Franklin, Stephen; Levonen, Anna-Liisa; Kensler, Thomas W.; Dinkova-Kostova, Albena T.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2019), 18 (4), 295-317CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Research)
      A review. The transcription factor NF-E2 p45-related factor 2 (NRF2; encoded by NFE2L2) and its principal neg. regulator, the E3 ligase adaptor Kelch-like ECH-assocd. protein 1 (KEAP1), are crit. in the maintenance of redox, metabolic and protein homeostasis, as well as the regulation of inflammation. Thus, NRF2 activation provides cytoprotection against numerous pathologies including chronic diseases of the lung and liver; autoimmune, neurodegenerative and metabolic disorders; and cancer initiation. One NRF2 activator has received clin. approval and several electrophilic modifiers of the cysteine-based sensor KEAP1 and inhibitors of its interaction with NRF2 are now in clin. development. However, challenges regarding target specificity, pharmacodynamic properties, efficacy and safety remain.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXlslKlsr0%253D&md5=ce3b8d39cd759418444f6e375ee1a38c
    7. 7
      Lu, M. C.; Ji, J. A.; Jiang, Z. Y.; You, Q. D. The Keap1-Nrf2-Are Pathway as a Potential Preventive and Therapeutic Target: An Update. Med. Res. Rev. 2016, 36, 924– 963,  DOI: 10.1002/med.21396
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      The Keap1-Nrf2-ARE Pathway As a Potential Preventive and Therapeutic Target: An Update
      Lu, Meng-Chen; Ji, Jian-Ai; Jiang, Zheng-Yu; You, Qi-Dong
      Medicinal Research Reviews (2016), 36 (5), 924-963CODEN: MRREDD; ISSN:0198-6325. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      A review. The Keap1-Nrf2-ARE ((Kelch-like ECH-Assocg. protein 1) nuclear factor erythroid 2 related factor 2-antioxidant response element) pathway is one of the most important defense mechanisms against oxidative and/or electrophilic stresses, and it is closely assocd. with inflammatory diseases, including cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, cardiovascular diseases, and aging. In recent years, progress has been made in strategies aimed at modulating the Keap1-Nrf2-ARE pathway. The Nrf2 activator DMF (Dimethylfumarates) has been approved by the FDA as a new first-line oral drug to treat patients with relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis, while a phase 3 study of another promising candidate, CDDO-Me, was terminated for safety reasons. Directly inhibiting Keap1-Nrf2 protein-protein interactions as a novel Nrf2-modulating strategy has many advantages over using electrophilic Nrf2 activators. The development of Keap1-Nrf2 protein-protein interaction inhibitors has become a topic of intense research, and potent inhibitors of this target have been identified. In addn., inhibiting Nrf2 activity has attracted an increasing amt. of attention because it may provide an alternative cancer therapy. This review summarizes the mol. mechanisms and biol. functions of the Keap1-Nrf2-ARE system. The main focus of this review is on recent progress in studies of agents that target the Keap1-Nrf2-ARE pathway and the therapeutic applications of such agents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtlSms7bL&md5=b5514acfaaa6ecb31efe0d75387dd56e
    8. 8
      Zhuang, C.; Wu, Z.; Xing, C.; Miao, Z. Small Molecules Inhibiting Keap1-Nrf2 Protein-Protein Interactions: A Novel Approach to Activate Nrf2 Function. MedChemComm 2017, 8, 286– 294,  DOI: 10.1039/C6MD00500D
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Small molecules inhibiting Keap1-Nrf2 protein-protein interactions: a novel approach to activate Nrf2 function
      Zhuang, Chunlin; Wu, Zhongli; Xing, Chengguo; Miao, Zhenyuan
      MedChemComm (2017), 8 (2), 286-294CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Oxidative stress is well recognized to contribute to the cause of a wide range of diseases, such as cancer, diabetes, Alzheimer's disease, arteriosclerosis, and inflammation. The Keap1-Nrf2-ARE pathway plays a crit. regulatory role and can protect cells from oxidative stress through activating Nrf2 to induce its downstream phase II enzymes. Nrf2 activation through the covalent inactivation of Keap1 may cause unpredictable side effects. Non-covalent disruption of the Keap1-Nrf2 protein-protein interactions is an alternative strategy for Nrf2 activation, potentially with reduced risk of toxicity. Efforts have been made in recent years to develop peptide- and small mol.-based Keap1-Nrf2 PPI inhibitors via different approaches, including high-throughput screening, target-based virtual screening, structure-based optimization, and fragment-based drug design. This review aims to highlight the recently discovered small-mol. inhibitors as well as their therapeutic potential.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVOgtr%252FM&md5=4b1419a777ebe5fc718899e36fece119

      Itoh, K.; Wakabayashi, N.; Katoh, Y.; Ishii, T.; Igarashi, K.; Engel, J. D.; Yamamoto, M. Keap1 Represses Nuclear Activation of Antioxidant Responsive Elements by Nrf2 through Binding to the Amino-Terminal Neh2 Domain. Genes Dev. 1999, 13, 76– 86,  DOI: 10.1101/gad.13.1.76
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Keap1 represses nuclear activation of antioxidant responsive elements by Nrf2 through binding to the amino-terminal Neh2 domain
      Itoh, Ken; Wakabayashi, Nobunao; Katoh, Yasutake; Ishii, Tetsuro; Igarashi, Kazuhiko; Engel, James Douglas; Yamamoto, Masayuki
      Genes & Development (1999), 13 (1), 76-86CODEN: GEDEEP; ISSN:0890-9369. (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press)
      Transcription factor Nrf2 is essential for the antioxidant responsive element 〈ARE〉-mediated induction of phase II detoxifying and oxidative stress enzyme genes. Detailed anal. of differential Nrf2 activity displayed in transfected cell lines ultimately led to the identification of a new protein, which we named Keap1, that suppresses Nrf2 transcriptional activity by specific binding to its evolutionarily conserved amino-terminal regulatory domain. The closest homolog of Keap1 is a Drosophila actin-binding protein called Kelch, implying that Keap1 might be a Nrf2 cytoplasmic effector. We then showed that electrophilic agents antagonize Keap1 inhibition of Nrf2 activity in vivo, allowing Nrf2 to traverse from the cytoplasm to the nucleus and potentiate the ARE response. We postulate that Keap1 and Nrf2 constitute a crucial cellular sensor for oxidative stress, and together mediate a key step in the signaling pathway that leads to transcriptional activation by this novel Nrf2 nuclear shuttling mechanism. The activation of Nrf2 leads in turn to the induction of phase II enzyme and antioxidative stress genes in response to electrophiles and reactive oxygen species.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXnvF2qsg%253D%253D&md5=1f6cdf6615b03719dedbffe01d0be2ec
    10. 10
      Itoh, K.; Wakabayashi, N.; Katoh, Y.; Ishii, T.; O’Connor, T.; Yamamoto, M. Keap1 Regulates Both Cytoplasmic-Nuclear Shuttling and Degradation of Nrf2 in Response to Electrophiles. Genes Cells 2003, 8, 379– 391,  DOI: 10.1046/j.1365-2443.2003.00640.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Keap1 regulates both cytoplasmic-nuclear shuttling and degradation of Nrf2 in response to electrophiles
      Itoh, Ken; Wakabayashi, Nobunao; Katoh, Yasutake; Ishii, Tetsuro; O'Connor, Tania; Yamamoto, Masayuki
      Genes to Cells (2003), 8 (4), 379-391CODEN: GECEFL; ISSN:1356-9597. (Blackwell Publishing Ltd.)
      Transcription factor Nrf2 regulates the expression of a set of detoxifying and anti-oxidant enzyme genes. Several lines of evidence suggest that electrophiles and reactive oxygen species liberate Nrf2 from its cytoplasmic repressor Keap1 and provoke the accumulation of Nrf2 in the nucleus. To elucidate the mol. mechanisms as to how Nrf2 is activated by inducers, we examd. the cytoplasmic-nuclear shuttling and turnover of Nrf2. We found that Nrf2 is rapidly degraded through the proteasome pathway, while electrophiles cause Nrf2 nuclear translocation with concomitant stabilization. Crucial to the inducible accumulation of Nrf2 is the enfeebling of the Nrf2-Keap1 interaction by electrophiles. Exploiting mice which have the LacZ reporter gene knocked into the nrf2 locus, we revealed that the inducible accumulation of Nrf2 protein by electrophiles in macrophages and intestinal epithelia could be recapitulated by the Nrf2 N-terminal region in combination with a nuclear localization signal. We also found constitutive Nrf2 nuclear accumulation in Keap1-deficient mouse macrophages. Our results highlight the fact that Nrf2 protein turnover is regulated by Keap1 mediated subcellular compartmentalization.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXivFOjuro%253D&md5=83c685153d60dc472a7537ea7b274f22
    11. 11
      Kobayashi, A.; Kang, M. I.; Okawa, H.; Ohtsuji, M.; Zenke, Y.; Chiba, T.; Igarashi, K.; Yamamoto, M. Oxidative Stress Sensor Keap1 Functions as an Adaptor for Cul3-Based E3 Ligase to Regulate Proteasomal Degradation of Nrf2. Mol. Cell.       [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Oxidative stress sensor Keap1 functions as an adaptor for Cul3-based E3 ligase to regulate proteasomal degradation of Nrf2
      Kobayashi, Akira; Kang, Moon-Il; Okawa, Hiromi; Ohtsuji, Makiko; Zenke, Yukari; Chiba, Tomoki; Igarashi, Kazuhiko; Yamamoto, Masayuki
      Molecular and Cellular Biology (2004), 24 (16), 7130-7139CODEN: MCEBD4; ISSN:0270-7306. (American Society for Microbiology)
      Transcription factor Nrf2 is a major regulator of genes encoding phase 2 detoxifying enzymes and antioxidant stress proteins in response to electrophilic agents and oxidative stress. In the absence of such stimuli, Nrf2 is inactive owing to its cytoplasmic retention by Keap1 and rapid degrdn. through the proteasome system. We examd. the contribution of Keap1 to the rapid turnover of Nrf2 (half-life of less than 20 min) and found that a direct assocn. between Keap1 and Nrf2 is required for Nrf2 degrdn. In a series of domain function analyses of Keap1, we found that both the BTB and intervening-region (IVR) domains are crucial for Nrf2 degrdn., implying that these two domains act to recruit ubiquitin-proteasome factors. Indeed, Cullin 3 (Cul3), a subunit of the E3 ligase complex, was found to interact specifically with Keap1 in vivo. Keap1 assocs. with the N-terminal region of Cul3 through the IVR domain and promotes the ubiquitination of Nrf2 in cooperation with the Cul3-Roc1 complex. These results thus provide solid evidence that Keap1 functions as an adaptor of Cul3-based E3 ligase. To our knowledge, Nrf2 and Keap1 are the first reported mammalian substrate and adaptor, resp., of the Cul3-based E3 ligase system.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXmtlOjt7w%253D&md5=3d6e356865cd6f33c800bf9124d7c8da
